text:
I'm experimenting with the old fashioned way on my personal site: narrating my own articles and embedding the audio

e.g. <https://www.ryanlaw.me/writing/pareto-principle>

this would be a pain for X00 articles, but it's pretty quick and straightforward for a handful.

also teaches you a lot about how conversational your writing is/isn't :sweat_smile:

attachments.text: Focus your energy on high-impact activities with this simple mental heuristic.

text: Hey :slightly_smiling_face: From my experience in the WordPress industry (in case you wish to build your website on WordPress) building a WordPress website using an LMS plugin and maintaining it, so that it runs smoothly is a process that needs a WordPress expert. In the best case scenario, when the courses start having a bigger audience and the traffic is big, those websites usually are heavy and need an expert to maintain them so that they run smoothly. So, you need to consider hiring an expert to run the technical issues with your website. The truth is that this way, you will be able to control and easily update the contents of your website and the available plugins do miracles in creating fascinating and interactive courses.

text:
Online courses are a big chunk of our business:

• At scale, it's a perpetual back-and-forth between "Should we pay a bunch of money for an LMS?" vs. "Should we develop our own LMS?" Probably a simpler decision for only a handful of courses.
• Remember that your primary competition is all the free stuff out there, not other paid courses.
• People love case studies that help explain principles and actionable content that includes supporting materials (e.g., spreadsheet templates).
• Few companies have dedicated "learning hours"; only the highly motivated tend to complete courses, which makes retention a struggle (industry wide).

Remember that your primary competition is all the free stuff out there, not other paid courses.
People love case studies that help explain principles and actionable content that includes supporting materials (e.g., spreadsheet templates).
Few companies have dedicated "learning hours"; only the highly motivated tend to complete courses, which makes retention a struggle (industry wide).

text:
I’m a team of one (only 2 months now) and I lead marketing + have a dedicated afternoon each week to support.

The best way I’ve been able to draw lines is outline clear goals on what I want to accomplish with marketing with my manager (CEO), write down a list of what will help us achieve those goals, and if anything is outside of that list (except for the occasional thing that pops up), I stay laser-focused on that. We add any new ideas to a “Q3” item in our agenda that we’ll revisit next quarter when we decide what we’d like to get done

text:
i feel like these answers will vary from company to company, but, for me, it's happened in a couple of ways:

1. *trying to fill the gaps.* we don't have a full-time copywriter in house. we generate a bunch of traffic but are under-optimized for email capture and lead nurturing. i jumped in to help write opt-in copy and create drip campaigns because greater success there connected the dots between the TOFU traffic i was mainly responsible for and revenue.
2. *creating a proof of concept.* i've worked on some tangents (e.g., outreach) to develop processes and show potential value _if_ we had someone working full time. that proof of concept allowed us to hire _after_ we knew something was likely to work and meant that we hired only after we'd already developed a solid process.

text:
I often talk about cutting your content a hundred ways.

A blog can be the basis of a script for a video, the audio from a video can be a podcast, the research can be a live talk, a live talk can be a video. Audio, Video and Writing are all connected.

The hard part is doing the research and articulating your thoughts. Once you've done that it's not too difficult to adapt it to other mediums.

text:
Hey Ben, I’m primarily working with B2B companies and here’s 89% of my methodology and process:
<https://dgajsek.com/content-marketing-playbook/>

The biggest difference between “vanilla” SEO content is deep research and continous weekly meetings with your client’s sales team. The organic traffic is great but you need to prove you’ve converted the right leads.

After deep research of clients value props and their customer pains, you include and address them into your content output.

I like to think in this way when it comes to creating converting content - will this be useful for the clients sales dept? Would Kevin send their prospect who is on the top of the sales funnel to this client to:
a) learn more about the recurring pains
b) build trust with the company
c) effectively follow up and continue the convo

<@UJG9WTEKG> hope it’s alright to share since it’s contextual.

attachments.title: How to do Content Marketing the Right Way - Dejan Gajsek
attachments.text: No immediate payback, immensive time commitment, and needs extreme planning to execute. Why would you even do content marketing? Is the juice worth the squeeze?
attachments.fallback: Dejan Gajsek: How to do Content Marketing the Right Way - Dejan Gajsek

text:
When pitching to a new client do you feel there’s a balance between providing an immediate fix and suggesting a slower strategic response that begins with research? We find these leads often come in as what they think is a ‘content brief’ but we’ve identified they don’t have a clear CVP or understanding of their customer journey.

Our challenge is to educate them on the benefit of a strategically planned content funnel that aligns to the user journey, while in a way still ‘answering their brief’

elements.text:
When pitching to a new client do you feel there’s a balance between providing an immediate fix and suggesting a slower strategic response that begins with research? We find these leads often come in as what they think is a ‘content brief’ but we’ve identified they don’t have a clear CVP or understanding of their customer journey.

Our challenge is to educate them on the benefit of a strategically planned content funnel that aligns to the user journey, while in a way still ‘answering their brief’

text:
In most cases you can solve the shorter term gratification itch with SEO TOFU content which leads to different content pieces. I do like to include distribution in the package (community outreach, paid outreach for a couple $ through FB lookalike) to score some trust points.

Saying that, you’re right, the education is the most important puzzle. Because you’re talking with client’s sales dept you can hand them out value docs (value prop table or objections) so they confirm and see you’re doing the work.

Since the channel is content marketing, telling that results takes time and the measure of success is primarily lead conversion and secondarily organic traffic volume is something you need to convey early on.
